unnormalised: A few days ago, I was at the local SBI branch near my house in Andheri. I needed to deposit ₹25000 in cash, a not-so-insignificant amount, into my mother’s account. Usually, I do everything online, UPI and all that, but she still prefers the old-fashioned way sometimes.
normalised: A few days ago, I was at the local S-B-I branch near my house in Andheri. I needed to deposit rupee twenty five thousand in cash, a not-so-insignificant amount, into my mother's account. Usually, I do everything online, U-P-I and all that, but she still prefers the old-fashioned way sometimes.

unnormalised: Anyway, I walked in, grabbed a deposit slip, and started filling it out. Name, account number (which is a long string of digits, something like 1234567890123), date (it was 27/10/2024), and the amount in both numerals and words. You know, the usual drill.
normalised: Anyway, I walked in, grabbed a deposit slip, and started filling it out. Name, account number (which is a long string of digits, something like one two three four five six seven eight nine zero one two three), date (it was twenty seventh october two thousand and twenty four), and the amount in both numerals and words. You know, the usual drill.

unnormalised: So, I reached the counter, and the clerk, a middle-aged guy in a slightly rumpled shirt, gave me a look. "Sir," he said, "do you have proper ID?" I showed him my Aadhaar card; the number's something like 9876-5432-1012, but he shook his head. "Rs. 25000 cash deposit requires PAN card copy," he stated plainly. I told him I had a soft copy on my phone if that would suffice, but he informed me that for amounts exceeding Rs. 20000, the rules clearly stated a physical copy was required for transactions at the counter.
normalised: So, I reached the counter, and the clerk, a middle-aged guy in a slightly rumpled shirt, gave me a look. "Sir," he said, "do you have proper I-D?" I showed him my Aadhaar card; the number's something like nine eight seven six dash five four three two dash one zero one two, but he shook his head. "rupee twenty five thousand cash deposit requires P-A-N card copy," he stated plainly. I told him I had a soft copy on my phone if that would suffice, but he informed me that for amounts exceeding rupee twenty thousand, the rules clearly stated a physical copy was required for transactions at the counter.

unnormalised: I sighed internally. Of course, I didn’t have a physical copy. Who carries those things around anymore? I even offered to show him my PAN card on the government's app, which is supposed to be perfectly valid ID, but no dice. "Rules are rules, sir," he said, with that official-sounding tone that government employees sometimes have.
normalised: I sighed internally. Of course, I didn't have a physical copy. Who carries those things around anymore? I even offered to show him my P-A-N card on the government's app, which is supposed to be perfectly valid I-D, but no dice. "Rules are rules, sir," he said, with that official-sounding tone that government employees sometimes have.

unnormalised: Frustrated, I stepped aside and called my younger brother, who thankfully lives nearby. I asked him to quickly run home and get my PAN card copy, since he keeps scanned documents of all our family members. It took him about 30 mins, and during that time, I contemplated using the cash deposit machine. But it had a daily limit of ₹49999 and I was planning to deposit more in the coming days. If I split it up like that, I’d need to go back every day!
normalised: Frustrated, I stepped aside and called my younger brother, who thankfully lives nearby. I asked him to quickly run home and get my P-A-N card copy, since he keeps scanned documents of all our family members. It took him about thirty minutes, and during that time, I contemplated using the cash deposit machine. But it had a daily limit of rupee forty nine thousand nine hundred and ninety nine and I was planning to deposit more in the coming days. If I split it up like that, I'd need to go back every day!

unnormalised: Finally, my brother arrived with the document. I handed it to the clerk, who meticulously checked it against the details on the deposit slip. He then gave me a receipt, stamped and everything, and I finally managed to deposit the cash.
normalised: Finally, my brother arrived with the document. I handed it to the clerk, who meticulously checked it against the details on the deposit slip. He then gave me a receipt, stamped and everything, and I finally managed to deposit the cash.

unnormalised: Honestly, the whole experience felt like a throwback to a bygone era. In this day and age, with UPI IDs and instant bank transfers, it seems crazy that depositing Rs. 25k still requires so much hassle. And a physical copy of a PAN card? I mean, really? The teller informed me that the bank could fine us Rs. 10000 if the cash deposit was done without adhering to KYC guidelines, which includes submitting my PAN copy.
normalised: Honestly, the whole experience felt like a throwback to a bygone era. In this day and age, with U-P-I I-Ds and instant bank transfers, it seems crazy that depositing rupee twenty five thousand still requires so much hassle. And a physical copy of a P-A-N card? I mean, really? The teller informed me that the bank could fine us rupee ten thousand if the cash deposit was done without adhering to K-Y-C guidelines, which includes submitting my P-A-N copy.
